dataset.title: Kachemak Bay Ecological Characterization Project - GIS data (1982-2000)

address.deliveryPoint: National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis, Unversity of California, Santa Barbara

abstract.para:
The KBEC GIS data layers are grouped and organized into a Data Inventory by "factors" that contribute to this Characterization (biological, geological, physical, human, etc.). The Data Inventory contains information about each spatial data theme, including a title/description of the data file, a link to the associated metadata record, and a sample thematic map. The "thematic map" for each image theme is simply a low-resolution version of the image, while the "thematic maps" for feature and grid themes generally display one particular attribute of the spatial data, keeping in mind that most themes have multiple attributes associated with them that are not displayed.
The KBEC GIS layers pertain to the physical environment, the estuarine environment, the terrestrial environment and also contains information about scores of plant and animal species that occur in the vicinity of Kachemak Bay to supplement multiple sections of the narrative. Additionally, layers cover social data including an historical perspectie of Kachemak Bay and a present-day perspective of human uses.
In general, these maps do not distinguish ubiquitous and/or wide-ranging species. Instead, the focus is on species with special habitat requirements provided by the areas in and around the Kachemak Bay Watershed. These maps are not comprehensive, but they do represent the current state of knowledge. They, therefore, help to illuminate the strengths and gaps in our collective knowledge base. Recall that detailed information on sources, coverage, etc. of the data layers can be found in the metadata.
Funders: The Kachemak Bay Ecological Characterization (KBEC) Project was a cooperative effort between the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Coastal Services Center, the Alaska Department of Fish and Game (ADF&G), and Kachemak Bay Research Reserve. Additional funding came from the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council and the National Spatial Data Infrastructure program. Please cite these data as follows: "Kachemak Bay Research Reserve and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Coastal Services Center. Kachemak Bay Ecological Characterization. CD-ROM. NOAA/CSC/20017-CD. Charleston, SC: NOAA Coastal Services Center. "

intellectualRights.para:
This material is based upon work funded by the Kachemak Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve, National Oceanic Atmospheric & Administration and Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views or positions of the these parties.
Standard scientific norms for attribution and credit should be followed when using these data including to the Owners, Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, the Kachemak Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve and National Oceanic Atmospheric & Administration. Please let the listed Owner know when these data are used. DATA MUST BE CITED AS FOLLOWS:
"Kachemak Bay Research Reserve and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Coastal Services Center. Kachemak Bay Ecological Characterization. CD-ROM. NOAA/CSC/20017-CD. Charleston, SC: NOAA Coastal Services Center. "
These data are licensed under CC0. The person who associated a work with this deed has dedicated the work to the public domain by waiving all of his or her rights to the work worldwide under copyright law, including all related and neighboring rights, to the extent allowed by law. You can copy, modify, distribute and perform the work, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission as long as the data are properly cited.

section.title: notes
section.para: Methods of collection are highly varied and include over 20 years of projects. See original project report for specific details.

The KBEC GIS database contains 14 newly created spatial data layers that depict species distribution and known resource use in the Kachemak Bay area. KBEC staff compiled the data necessary to produce these particular themes. They contain information from a variety of sources including:
•Alaska Department of Fish and Game Critical Habitat Area Maps
•Maps from the Land Trusts in Alaska / Kachemak Heritage Land Trust Mapping Project
•Interviews with knowledgeable local experts and professionals.

In general, these maps do not distinguish ubiquitous and/or wide-ranging species. Instead, the focus is on species with special habitat requirements provided by the areas in and around the Kachemak Bay Watershed. These maps are not comprehensive, but they do represent the current state of knowledge. They, therefore, help to illuminate the strengths and gaps in our collective knowledge base. Recall that detailed information on sources, coverage, etc. of the data layers can be found in the metadata.

section.title: GIS remarks
section.para: Most of the information depicted by these themes was referenced to 1:63,360 USGS topographic maps. Therefore, during the data production phase, and where applicable, KBEC staff fit the data to the coastline using arcs from the COASTST theme, which is also based on 1:63,360 USGS topographic maps.

Since some areas have more than one species and/or resource use associated with them, many of the distribution and resource use data layers have regions that "overlap" one another. Those data layers with a high degree of overlap are not conducive for mapping and display purposes. A user can attempt to map or display the data through the creative use of hatch patterns and transparent backgrounds to show areas of overlap. One can also query the data to influence display of specefic features of interest. For assistance in querying the data layers of the KBEC GIS, and manipulating their legends, refer to the tutorials.

Upon close inspection of the data within a GIS software package, users will undoubtedly realize that the themes do not always overlay or line up well. This is most likely due to one or more of the following reasons:
Different scales - A data layer created at the 1:2,000,000 scale will not have the detail found within a theme that depicts features at the 1:63,360 scale.

Different original projections - All the data layers within the KBEC GIS database have the same projection parameters (see any KBEC metadata record for details). However, some of the themes were originally referenced by geographic, UTM, or State Plane coordinates, and/or projected using a different datum. Because of the rounding errors associated with the projection process, a theme is potentially degraded each time it is projected. (Note: for more information on map projections and how to change them, see related section: ArcView GIS Tutorials.)
Different basemap - The sources of the data may differ. For example, some of the data layers were digitized from USGS topographic maps, while others were digitized from aerial photographs.

Different coastline - The KBEC GIS contains two coastline themes (COASTST and COAST63) (Data Inventory; Physical). Some of the data layers contain arcs that coincide with the COASTST theme, whereas other data layers borrowed arcs from COAST63. COASTST is essentially based on 1:63,360 USGS topographic maps, while COAST63 is a photo-revised version based on high-altitude aerial photography. The differences are most apparent at the head of Kachemak Bay in the Fox River Flats area, and along the Homer Spit; although numerous other differences exist (i.e., islands, spits).

The KBEC GIS database is by no means complete. There are numerous spatial data layers known to exist that also contain data associated with the Kachemak Bay area. However, due to time constraints and various other reasons, these themes were left out of this GIS. Some additional information may be obtained from outside GIS-related projects and sites.

funding.para: Kachemak Bay Research Reserve; National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration Coastal Services Center; Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council project numbers 99278, 00278; Alaska Department of Fish & Game

dataTable.entityDescription: GIS data layer index and categories, KBEC

attribute.attributeDefinition: Layers with biodiversity data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with fisheries data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with forestry data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with growth management and planning data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with hydrology and water quality data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with marine transport data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with tourism and recreation data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with waste disposal data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
Layers with wildlife habitat and distribution data will have a '1' in this column, otherwise a '0' will be present
